main_text:
David Hume’s views on aesthetic theory and the philosophy of art
are to be found in his work on moral theory and in several essays.
Although there is a tendency to emphasize the two essays devoted to
art, “Of the Standard of Taste” and “Of
Tragedy,” his views on art and aesthetic judgment are intimately
connected to his moral philosophy and theories of human thought and
emotion. His theory of taste and beauty is not entirely original, but
his arguments generally display the keen analysis typical of his best
work. Hume’s archaic terminology is occasionally an obstacle to
appreciating his analysis, inviting conflicting readings of his
position.
